articles.headline: 12 Russian Agents Indicted in Mueller Investigation
articles.snippet: The intelligence officers were charged with hacking Democrats during the 2016 campaign. The indictment was announced days before President Trump is to meet with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia.
articles.abstract: The intelligence officers were charged with hacking Democrats during the 2016 campaign. The indictment was announced days before President Trump is to meet with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The special counsel investigating Russian interference in the 2016 election issued an indictment of 12 Russian intelligence officers on Friday in the hacking of the Democratic National Committee and the Clinton presidential campaign. The indictment came only three days before President Trump was planning to meet with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia in Helsinki, Finland.
articles.byline: By Mark Mazzetti and Katie Benner

articles.headline: Trump Invited the Russians to Hack Clinton. Were They Listening?
articles.snippet: The same day that Donald J. Trump asked Russians for help in hacking Hillary Clinton’s emails, Russia began efforts to target her personal servers.
articles.abstract: The same day that Donald J. Trump asked Russians for help in hacking Hillary Clinton’s emails, Russia began efforts to target her personal servers.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — It was one of the more outlandish statements in a campaign replete with them: In a news conference in July 2016, Donald J. Trump made a direct appeal to Russia to hack Hillary Clinton’s emails and make them public.

articles.headline: Paychecks Lag as Profits Soar, and Prices Erode Wage Gains
articles.snippet: Fears of an overheated economy could prompt the Federal Reserve to cut short a recovery in which incomes have already struggled to gain traction.
articles.abstract: Fears of an overheated economy could prompt the Federal Reserve to cut short a recovery in which incomes have already struggled to gain traction.
articles.lead_paragraph: Corporate profits have rarely swept up a bigger share of the nation’s wealth, and workers have rarely shared a smaller one.

articles.headline: At Uber, New Questions Arise About Executive Behavior
articles.snippet: As Uber cleans up its corporate culture, employees have filed complaints about the chief operating officer, Barney Harford, for his comments about race and women.
articles.abstract: As Uber cleans up its corporate culture, employees have filed complaints about the chief operating officer, Barney Harford, for his comments about race and women.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Barney Harford was hired late last year to help fix problems at Uber, the ride-hailing company. Instead, he has created new ones.
articles.byline: By Mike Isaac and Katie Benner

articles.headline: A Crisis Management Guru Bungles a Crisis
articles.snippet: Sir Alan Parker, one of Britain’s most famous corporate strategists, resigned from Save the Children U.K. over his handling of a #MeToo scandal. It has cast a long shadow.
articles.abstract: Sir Alan Parker, one of Britain’s most famous corporate strategists, resigned from Save the Children U.K. over his handling of a #MeToo scandal. It has cast a long shadow.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — When Sir Alan Parker was appointed chairman of Save the Children U.K. in 2008, he must have seemed like the perfect choice. As the founder and head of Brunswick Group, one of the most successful corporate public relations firms in the world, he had connections with chief executives, celebrities and media moguls as well as politicians on both sides of the political divide. Charming and boyishly effusive, he earned millions leading a business that now has 1,000 employees in 14 countries, all of them shaping narratives for companies in the public eye.

articles.headline: Forget Suits. Show the Tattoo. Female Candidates Are Breaking the Rules.
articles.snippet: After years of being told to put on a suit and recite their résumé, women running for office are now revealing themselves in more complex ways.
articles.abstract: After years of being told to put on a suit and recite their résumé, women running for office are now revealing themselves in more complex ways.
articles.lead_paragraph: The guys at the union hall have just swapped out the first keg when Abby Finkenauer, Democratic candidate for Congress, arrives and immediately reveals the kind of vulnerability that campaign consultants have long told women to avoid.

articles.headline: Cleaning Toilets, Following Rules: A Migrant Child’s Days in Detention
articles.snippet: A portrait of life in the shelters for the children detained after crossing the U.S.-Mexico border.
articles.abstract: A portrait of life in the shelters for the children detained after crossing the U.S.-Mexico border.
articles.lead_paragraph: Do not misbehave. Do not sit on the floor. Do not share your food. Do not use nicknames. Also, it is best not to cry. Doing so might hurt your case.
articles.byline: By Dan Barry, Miriam Jordan, Annie Correal and Manny Fernandez

articles.headline: The Education of a Brotelier
articles.snippet: With the help of a few famous friends, Ben Weprin is developing a chain of boutique hotels in university towns that relies heavily on nostalgia for college life.
articles.abstract: With the help of a few famous friends, Ben Weprin is developing a chain of boutique hotels in university towns that relies heavily on nostalgia for college life.
articles.lead_paragraph: Wearing a red vintage T-shirt, an Eric Church baseball cap and a backpack, Ben Weprin bound down a sidewalk of Roosevelt Island in New York, home of the Cornell Tech campus, a satellite of Cornell University, looking like a college student on the first day of class.

articles.headline: Youth Soccer Participation Has Fallen Significantly in America
articles.snippet: Not having the American team in the tournament robbed officials of an opportunity to re-energize the sport among youth distracted by other diversions.
articles.abstract: Not having the American team in the tournament robbed officials of an opportunity to re-energize the sport among youth distracted by other diversions.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — With its gables, turrets and iron railing, U.S. Soccer House — as the mansion housing the U.S. Soccer Federation is known — looks more like a fortress than the headquarters of a major sports organization. It is fitting: The federation is on the defensive.

articles.headline: Influential Judge, Loyal Friend, Conservative Warrior — and D.C. Insider
articles.snippet: The carefully crafted narrative around Brett Kavanaugh, President Trump’s Supreme Court nominee, plays down his legacy as a charter member of elite Washington.
articles.abstract: The carefully crafted narrative around Brett Kavanaugh, President Trump’s Supreme Court nominee, plays down his legacy as a charter member of elite Washington.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Judge Brett M. Kavanaugh introduced himself to the American people on Monday, with a beaming President Trump beside him, he had a lot to say about his mother, a former high school teacher and a Maryland judge. He accorded his father strikingly less attention — just 34 words, compared with 132 about his mother — mentioning his “unparalleled work ethic” while not saying exactly what work he did.
articles.byline: By Scott Shane, Steve Eder, Rebecca R. Ruiz, Adam Liptak, Charlie Savage and Ben Protess

articles.headline: Trump Opens His Arms to Russia. His Administration Closes Its Fist.
articles.snippet: Whether it is Russia’s interference in the election, its annexation of Crimea, or its intervention in Syria, Mr. Trump’s statements either undercut, or flatly contradict, those of his lieutenants.
articles.abstract: Whether it is Russia’s interference in the election, its annexation of Crimea, or its intervention in Syria, Mr. Trump’s statements either undercut, or flatly contradict, those of his lieutenants.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — It was a jarring moment, even for an American leader whose curious attraction to Russia has often resulted in mixed messages from the United States.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler and Julie Hirschfeld Davis

articles.headline: Croatia, Cast in Underdog Role, Has the Look of a Champion
articles.snippet: Croatia does not have the economic power of France. It does not have its talent pool. But it will not, by any stretch of the imagination, be underestimated.
articles.abstract: Croatia does not have the economic power of France. It does not have its talent pool. But it will not, by any stretch of the imagination, be underestimated.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Something was bothering Croatia’s players and staff members as they reflected on the game that had brought them to the brink of greatness, and on the month that may culminate in what would — by most estimations — be the greatest achievement in World Cup history.

articles.headline: Warren Is Preparing for 2020. So Are Biden, Booker, Harris and Sanders.
articles.snippet: As many top Democrats eye a run for president in 2020, Elizabeth Warren has all but announced her candidacy, while Joe Biden is planning to campaign up to four days a week this fall for midterm candidates.
articles.abstract: As many top Democrats eye a run for president in 2020, Elizabeth Warren has all but announced her candidacy, while Joe Biden is planning to campaign up to four days a week this fall for midterm candidates.
articles.lead_paragraph: RENO, Nev. — During a campaign-style tour of the West late last month, Senator Elizabeth Warren did not announce she was running for president. But in private events and public speeches, her message about 2020 was as clear as it was rousing.
articles.byline: By Alexander Burns and Jonathan Martin

articles.headline: Just Sitting Down With Trump, Putin Comes Out Ahead
articles.snippet: By attacking Europe and starting a trade war with America’s closest allies, President Trump has already advanced the agenda of President Vladimir V. Putin, analysts say.
articles.abstract: By attacking Europe and starting a trade war with America’s closest allies, President Trump has already advanced the agenda of President Vladimir V. Putin, analysts say.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — When President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia sits down with President Trump in Helsinki, Finland, on Monday for a meeting he has long wanted, he will already have accomplished virtually everything he could reasonably hope for.
articles.byline: By Andrew Higgins and Neil MacFarquhar

articles.headline: How Israel, in Dark of Night, Torched Its Way to Iran’s Nuclear Secrets
articles.snippet: The Israeli government showed three reporters, including one from The Times, documents indicating that the Iranian nuclear weapons program was larger and more sophisticated than once suspected.
articles.abstract: The Israeli government showed three reporters, including one from The Times, documents indicating that the Iranian nuclear weapons program was larger and more sophisticated than once suspected.
articles.lead_paragraph: TEL AVIV — The Mossad agents moving in on a warehouse in a drab commercial district of Tehran knew exactly how much time they had to disable the alarms, break through two doors, cut through dozens of giant safes and get out of the city with a half-ton of secret materials: six hours and 29 minutes.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger and Ronen Bergman

articles.headline: France, a World Cup Champion That Stood Above It All in Russia
articles.snippet: France always felt out of place in Russia, winning with an air of cultivated detachment, as though it were competing in a completely different tournament.
articles.abstract: France always felt out of place in Russia, winning with an air of cultivated detachment, as though it were competing in a completely different tournament.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — They waited until it was over, until the fireworks shot into the sky and the rain soaked them to the skin, until that glistening trophy was safe in their hands and golden confetti sparkled in their hair.

articles.headline: Amazon’s Curious Case of the $2,630.52 Used Paperback
articles.snippet: Booksellers on the online marketplace are charging thousands for books that normally sell for a few dollars. Authors are perplexed — and annoyed.
articles.abstract: Booksellers on the online marketplace are charging thousands for books that normally sell for a few dollars. Authors are perplexed — and annoyed.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Many booksellers on Amazon strive to sell their wares as cheaply as possible. That, after all, is usually how you make a sale in a competitive marketplace.

articles.headline: Inside the Mating Rituals of Brands and Online Stars
articles.snippet: With deals collectively worth billions of dollars at stake, the pressure is on advertisers and viral performers on sites like YouTube and Instagram to find the right match.
articles.abstract: With deals collectively worth billions of dollars at stake, the pressure is on advertisers and viral performers on sites like YouTube and Instagram to find the right match.
articles.lead_paragraph: ANAHEIM, Calif. — Recently at the Anaheim Convention Center, about 50 people entered a room decorated as a stylish lounge for a speed dating event. They moved from table to table every 20 minutes, exchanging small talk and getting to know each other.

articles.headline: White House Orders Direct Taliban Talks to Jump-Start Afghan Negotiations
articles.snippet: As patience with the long war fades, diplomats have expanded authority to begin talks with the Taliban, which could grow into broader negotiations.
articles.abstract: As patience with the long war fades, diplomats have expanded authority to begin talks with the Taliban, which could grow into broader negotiations.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — The Trump administration has told its top diplomats to seek direct talks with the Taliban, a significant shift in American policy in Afghanistan, done in the hope of jump-starting negotiations to end the 17-year war.
articles.byline: By Mujib Mashal and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: Tracing Guccifer 2.0’s Many Tentacles in the 2016 Election
articles.snippet: The indictment of 12 Russian operatives provides never-before-seen detail about the central role of the online avatar Guccifer 2.0 in the dissemination of stolen Democratic documents.
articles.abstract: The indictment of 12 Russian operatives provides never-before-seen detail about the central role of the online avatar Guccifer 2.0 in the dissemination of stolen Democratic documents.
articles.lead_paragraph: The message from WikiLeaks in July 2016 to a group of Russian intelligence officers who prosecutors say were posing as a Romanian hacker named Guccifer 2.0 urged swift action before the opening of the Democratic National Convention that month.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger, Jim Rutenberg and Eric Lipton

articles.headline: After Storm, Foreclosures in Puerto Rico Stopped. They’re Starting Again.
articles.snippet: Wall Street investors and banks are beginning to file foreclosure cases in the United States territory as several moratoriums come to an end.
articles.abstract: Wall Street investors and banks are beginning to file foreclosure cases in the United States territory as several moratoriums come to an end.
articles.lead_paragraph: The foreclosure machine that ground to a halt in Puerto Rico after the devastation caused by Hurricane Maria in September is slowly cranking up again. Island residents who fell behind on their payments are facing creditors ranging from Wall Street to the federal government.

articles.headline: He Preyed on Men Who Wanted to Be Priests. Then He Became a Cardinal.
articles.snippet: Cardinal Theodore E. McCarrick was removed from ministry last month for sexually abusing an altar boy. But for decades, the church overlooked his harassment of adult seminarians.
articles.abstract: Cardinal Theodore E. McCarrick was removed from ministry last month for sexually abusing an altar boy. But for decades, the church overlooked his harassment of adult seminarians.
articles.lead_paragraph: As a young man studying to be a priest in the 1980s, Robert Ciolek was flattered when his brilliant, charismatic bishop in Metuchen, N.J., Theodore E. McCarrick, told him he was a shining star, cut out to study in Rome and rise high in the church.
articles.byline: By Laurie Goodstein and Sharon Otterman

articles.headline: Looking Through the Eyes of China’s Surveillance State
articles.snippet: A rare chance to try on a tool of a would-be surveillance dystopia gave a glimpse of the wariness that a closely watched populace can’t hide.
articles.abstract: A rare chance to try on a tool of a would-be surveillance dystopia gave a glimpse of the wariness that a closely watched populace can’t hide.
articles.lead_paragraph: ZHENGZHOU, China — They perch on poles and glare from streetlamps. Some hang barely visible in the ceiling of the subway, and others seem to stretch out on braced necks and peer into your eyes.
